educational_objective: Diagnose sarcoidosis-related hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest CT scan.
question_text: A 27-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated for incidentally discovered hilar enlargement on chest radiography. CT of the chest is performed.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is stage I pulmonary sarcoidosis (hilar lymphadenopathy with normal lung parenchyma) (Option C). This chest CT scan shows lymphadenopathy. The scan is at a level just below the carina. It shows marked enlargement of lymph nodes in both hila (white arrows) and enlargement of a subcarinal lymph node (black arrow). Stage I pulmonary sarcoidosis is generally asymptomatic. Approximately 50% of all patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis are asymptomatic, with the disease incidentally detected on chest imaging performed for unrelated indications. (AAo = ascending aorta; DAo = descending aorta; LMB = left mainstem bronchus; RMB = right mainstem bronchus; RPA = right pulmonary artery.)
